Award.AwardTitle: Support of Campus Cyberinfrastructure at Non-Research Intensive and EPSCoR Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This two-year project enhances campus network infrastructure and external connectivity of colleges and universities having notable research projects, even though the institution may not be primarily research-focused. It offers workshops focused on campus infrastructures and external connectivity to support research and teaching, and "Tiger Team" campus visits to assist with technical implementation. It builds upon Internet2's track record in campus infrastructure enhancement, campus-focused network performance workshops, and tools to foster intra- and inter-campus collaboration; it also supports NSF efforts on behalf of under-represented institutions and those in states identified in the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) program, to upgrade infrastructures and enhance research and non-research activities. The workshops cover technical, organizational, and administrative aspects of upgraded campus infrastructure and high-bandwidth (1, 10, 40, 100 Gb/s) external connectivity. The Tiger Team visits will include expert advice on technical implementation, and Network Administrator and CIO-level administrative issues. It will result in a Best Practices manual informed by the project's findings. The project broadens the volume of campuses capable of participating in campus cyberinfrastructure-based projects, such as the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) and Campus Cyberinfrastructure-Network Infrastructure and Engineering (CC-NIE) award collaboration, and uses standard communications mechanisms (including Internet2's website) to broadly disseminate project findings. This will have a broad impact from analysis of solutions to barriers and needs in campus cyberinfrastructure, and the benefit non-research-intensive campuses that would not participate otherwise, including remote instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to support enhancement of campus network infrastructure and external connectivity of colleges and universities, including but not limited to those in EPSCoR states, having notable research projects, even though the institution may not have been primarily research-focused.  The project offered: four regional workshops focused on campus infrastructure (CI) and external connectivity to support research and teaching and 30 campus visits to non-research intensive institutions to assist them in understanding the role of CI in research and education, development of campus CI plans, seeking external funding for campus CI implementation, and deploying campus CI awards.

The project’s regional workshops were held in Kansas City, MO; Salt Lake City, UT; Raleigh, NC; and Dallas, TX and included a total of 136 participants representing 81 institutions. The 30 campus site visits involved 69 institutions representing 23 states (including 11 EPSCoR jurisdictions). The project team also produced a document including recommended practices based on lessons learned from workshops and campus visits addressing planning and deployment of campus CI, working effectively with regional networks, and effective ways to achieve external funding.  This document can be found at: https://spaces.internet2.edu/display/RE/Internet2+Campus+CI+Best+Practices+Manual.

The project benefited a broad scope of institutions through the outcomes achieved in its regional workshops, campus site visits, and manual outlining recommended practices.   Because of these, campuses with geographic and demographic diversity were able to develop and deploy sustainable Campus CI plans, and compete successfully for a broad spectrum of NSF-funded Campus CI awards in a wide range of disciplines, including aerospace and systems engineering, astrophysics, human and plant genomics, neuroscience, biotechnology, cybersecurity and big data, psychology, mathematics, biophysics, high-energy physics, microscopy, computational chemistry, astronomy, engineering, climate studies, statistics, epidemiology, toxicology, and earth science.  The project also impacted activities funded through XSEDE and GENI initiatives.

The project built upon and enhanced the efficacy, range, and sustainable impact of NSF’s multi-year investment in Campus Cyberinfrastructure by: broadening the reach of these opportunities to non-research intensive and EPSCoR campuses, expanding the demographic and geographic accessibility of campuses to NSF opportunities, assisting less experienced campuses in the development of effective long-term and sustainable campus CI planning, and offering consultation and support for sponsored research proposal.  The project resulted in the ability of campuses to identify challenges, enhance regional partnerships and make more effective use of Internet2-facilited advanced network resources- particularly for campuses that had not been able to do so previously.  As a result, many of these campuses were better positioned to participate in big data research collaborations, offer and expand curricula involving remote instruction and big data science, accommodate growth in students choosing STEM majors, and recruit and retain faculty whose research required improved campus CI.
